title: RIP Forgiven :(
body: Mandatory army service means we won't see him play after tomorrow for a year or so.

yes, not to mention that conscription is a pretty outdated concept imo.

Let me tell you a couple things of mandatory service.

First of all it is not a job. Mandatory service pay little exept if there are special conditions (like many siblings or guardian of the family). And still it is a raise from 5 to 30 euros. While needing at least 50 per month for when you go out. Yippe kay ye.

Second of all. You dont learn teamwork or team-building. On the contrary you learn to hide from responsibilities as much as possible. Let someone else take the responsibility or the blame. Teamwork is a blatant myth, everyone try to spend their time doing as less as possible. And you cant really blame them. Mandatory service is like a tax you pay in time.

Third. You learn few essential skills for your life. Most of the work you do are the simplest everyday jobs. Like cleaning everything over and over again. Most of the stuff you already know how to do or at least you would learn anyway in the months you are drafted. As for the physical training, being done by people that dont know what to do will often lead to burnouts. I would rather have someone with experience giving me a route i could follow twice a day instead of feeling exhausted for two days after that.

Expanding to point three. Unless you fall under certain exceptions (doctor electrician plumper and cook being the most obvious) you wont excersise your education. It was sad seeing people with degrees on lookouts and patrols.

As you can see mandatory service is not something pleasant for someone not caring to join the army. If it was my choise i would tolerate those, but since it was not in my hand, i considered those wasted months.

forgive my american brethren, military propaganda is vicious here. They do their best to make it seem like the military is the place of ultimate self-discovery. This is all to sell the idea to desperate (mostly) young boys. So Americans replying here will have these weird ideas about mandatory services

I understand. If i had the choise and wanted to join the militry along with earning decent amount of money i would do it. That is how i imagine work there. But here it is not optional, you are forced. I call it time tax for a reason. I just hope Forgiven goes into a support division as it is more relaxed there but still its 9 months kinda halting his life.

It is different in America; military service is voluntary (barring the Selective Service, but short of another world war, that will never be used). Service in the US military pays (maybe not well, but it pays) and has perks like free education.

In the case of mandatory service, it is the government looking to throw bodies and whatever menial task they need accomplished. They have no reason to incentivize people since their people have no choice.

This creates inherent differences in the experiences of those who serve and the perspectives of those commenting (on both sides of the fence).

I would man up, and do my job if the U.S. reactivated the draft.  I would go back in if I got cleared to.  I would make that sacrifice.  Hell, if I hadn't gotten injured, my next duty station would've been in Korea for 1-2 years.  For those that don't know, Korea is considered a hardship tour.  1-2 years where I couldn't return to the States, whether to visit family, women I was banging, or any job I had.  1-2 years in an area that's always tense, in the event that North Korea follows through on its desire to mount South Korea.  I'd embrace the suck, and do the best I could, and look at things with an open perspective where I'm stationed.

   My feelings don't matter.  What matters, is my getting the job done, having the back of those next to me, and conducting myself with honor, with integrity.  Do I run the risk of getting fucked over by those around me?  Yep.  It's happened before.  Can't control that.  Can only control my behavior, and move forward.

The probability of a person dying, is 1 in 1.  It's up to you whether you make the best or worst of any situation you're stuck in.  Me?  I see it as another step in life, and an opportunity.
